text: great book. make smart use of naltrexone and/or glutamine if you need them to calm cravings. add in good nutrition and exercise too.
in the case of alcohol, targeted naltrexone is very effective in slowly tapering. some see a 40% reduction the first week. wonderful tedx talk https://youtu.be/6eghiy_s2ts

targeted naltrexone. if you take one little pill, one hour before drinking, you will be targeting the part of the brain that makes alcohol so important to you. in a few months, alcohol (and the med) becomes very unimportant to you. the sinclair method. https://www.amazon.com/gp/video/detail/b07nbwmh9d

it's not a surprise that every person reacts differently to a powerful drug, and alcohol is certainly a powerful drug. for many, the logical brain (the neocortex) is simply overcome by alcohol and the amygdala takes charge. this emotional 'lizard brain' isn't very responsible.

so true. all brains learn things that bring pleasure (amygdala, dopamine) - and in the case of alcohol, at the expense of all normal joys in life. get the normal joys in life back ... by unlearning alcohol. by forgetting alcohol.

do you wish you only drank, say, once a week (or month) and always in control of the alcohol? would you take one pill once a week (or month) to stay in control? do you know it's very possible ...even if you are currently totally out of control. tedx talk https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6eghiy_s2ts&t=41s

this book is a breath of fresh air for aud sufferers, especially for the 90% who never seek treatment because of the embarrassment, the shame and the guilt of the old rehab methods .... the terribly daunting barriers to entry. not in 2020 !

"even if you have not stopped drinking, you can start taking naltrexone. the sinclair method is an alternative way to quit drinking that does not require inpatient detox treatment programs. patients who follow tsm protocols take naltrexone and reduce their drinking gradually."

"also known as tsm, the sinclair method is a way of reducing and quitting alcohol use by retraining the brain through “pharmacological extinction.” - a novel and effective harmreduction method. bravo !

if these things are a problem for you, then here is a book you must read ! relapse alcohol gambling addiction no shame, no guilt ... just pure science and the method that can get you back to good health. check your local library for a copy.
and ria health knows how to reduce your intake to much healthier levels - and to reduce or eliminate your cravings for alcohol. give them a call and see how.

alcohol changes the liver. alcohol changes the brain first through learning. both can be reversed. the learning can be "unlearned" using pavlovian science if done the right way. lots of info on the sinclair method. tedx & youtube.

don't rule out m.a.t. in fact - it's one of the best ways to make alcohol less and less important in your life, until one day it's very very unimportant. documentary "one little pill" free on amazon prime. lots more info on youtube.

many (imo most) alcoholics can be "cured" just as a type2 diabetic can be "cured". there is even a medication to keep them from slipping back into the addiction. naltrexone. tsm. lots of info on youtube.

yes indeed, by taking one pill of naltrexone instead before drinking, you can still enjoy the drink. the difference is your tendency to overdrink is reduced substantially. some can reduce their intake by 40% in the first week. in 4-12 months, alcohol just isn't important anymore!

but quiting gradually is rarely successful using willpower alone. that is why using a targeted med like naltrexone is so helpful in easing the process all the way to near or full abstinence. awesome method.
bit of a long shot but there is med that could be used short-term to help unlearn the habit. dm me if interested.

what people don't realize about tsm is the meds are targeted - used only as-needed. the meds stop for good if you decide you are done with alcohol. no cravings = no need to drink. once the brain has healed itself and you no longer crave alcohol, you have your life back. cool !
or perhaps a sign your treatment method is not working for you. there are many good options today.
could the sleeplessness, that coincides with alcohol abuse, contribute to increased inflammation/microglia, (& cells not getting cleaned out during normal restful sleep)?
it would be awesome to have another proven medical treatment for aud. the sinclair method is over 70% effective, but some people do not respond to naltrexone.

i think the mandatory 100% "abstinence model" - for life - is the main problem. even teetotalers couldn't easily say they will never touch wine or beer again. i believe abstinence is great, but there are science-based ways to get to 98-100% abstinence, cravings free.

there is good science to prove that naltrexone alone and exercise alone, each will have a very positive impact on lessening cravings. taken together is a no brainer. if exercise doesn't do it for you, naltrexone will !

imo choice is severely impaired. my experience, when you abruptly take alcohol away from a person who has relied on it for years (to relax, to socialize, to forget, to sleep) - they are pre-occupied with thoughts of alcohol ... fighting the urge, one day at a time, for years.
it starts as a choice, but once addicted, the ability to choose is fully disfunctional.

i think the main reason is in the addicted state, the brain has been fully rewired to fire on triggers and memories of these 'pleasures'. the trick is to rewire the brain back to the preaddicted state ...i.e. 'forget' these damn triggers. pavlov style.
